title: James Nasmyth, Engineer: An Autobiography
author: Nasmyth, James
snippet: A splendid prospect was seen fromthe upper windows; and especially from the Belvidere, which he hadconstructed on the summit of the roof.

title: Waverley Novels. (Abbotsford edition.)
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: which has Oecn a matter of such consequence totheir estate; and yet Mr Mowbray set himself againstme, my lord, in every possible sort of way, and encouraged the under-bred people about him to behavevery strangely.—There was the business of buildingthe Belvidere, which he would not permit to bcdone out of the stock-purse of the company, becauseI had given the workmen the plan aud the orders— and then, about the tea-room — and the hourfor beginning dancing — and about the subscriptionfor Mr Rymour's new Tale of Chivalry — in short,I owe no consideration to Mr Mowbray of St Ronan's."

title: Waverley Novels. (Abbotsford edition.)
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: I will send them such lots of landscapeswith sap-green trees, and mazareen-blue rivers, andportraits that will terrify the originals themselves— and handkerchiefs and turbaus, with needle-workscalloped exactly like the walks on the Belvidere—Why, I shall become a Uttle fortune in the firstseason."

title: Waverley Novels. (Abbotsford edition.)
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: "And, Dinah, bring the sugar —the soft EastIndia sugar, Dinah — and a lemon, Dinah, one ofthose which came fresh to-day — Go fetch it fromthe bar, Toby — and don't tumble down stairs, ifyou can help it.—And Dinah — stay, Dinah — thenutmeg, Dinah, and the ginger, my good girl And, Dinah — put the cushion up behind my back— and the footstool to my foot, for my toe is something the worse of my walk with your ladyship thismorning to the top of Belvidere."
